0307341569|4.0|As a fan of mystery and crime novels, I found Gillian Flynn's [[ASIN:0307341569 Dark Places: A Novel]] to be a compelling page-turner that, even as it trotted out one unlikable character after another and strained to impress its sense of utter despair upon me, hooked me on its central \\"whodunit?\\" question and consistently kept me wanting to solve the mystery to the very end.     The novel centers around the character of Libby Day, a thirtysomething woman who, at the age of seven, had survived the brutal massacre of her mother and two older sisters on their Kansas farm. Libby's testimony in the aftermath of the murders helped to put her older brother, Ben, behind bars for life for the crime, and she spends the next twenty-five years trying not to think about the incident, while simultaneously being unable to ever move past it. All of that changes, though, when Libby is contacted by a group of people who are convinced that Ben is innocent, and the story follows Libby's journey as she confronts the ghosts of her past to reveal the truth of what happened on that awful night.     The story uses an interesting narrative structure, as the point-of-view alternates between Libby in the present day and the various members of her family on the day leading up to the murders. As Libby delves deeper into her investigation, the author gradually unveils the parallel story of the murders themselves, culminating in a climax to each storyline that brings everything to a satisfying conclusion.    While the plot itself is strong, my enthusiasm was tempered a bit by the largely unlikable cast of characters. Libby, as well as just about everyone she meets along her journey, and in addition to the majority of the characters from the storyline of her family's past, is a human train wreck, even considering the circumstances of her life. Most of the rest of the cast of characters is equally pathetic, at times almost comically so, which can make the book seem as though it is depressing just for the sake of being depressing.     These are minor annoyances, though, as the central mystery is strong enough to make up for the overbearing characterizations. The only other small complaint I had was that the circumstances surrounding the night of the murders seem to involve an incredible number of extreme coincidences, but not enough to overshadow the overall story. To anyone who enjoys a good mystery yarn, I highly recommend [[ASIN:0307341569 Dark Places: A Novel]].
B00284BMBM|5.0|It took a high level of justified self-confidence for Daughtry to follow their blockbuster debut album with one that gives a nod to its predecessor while at the same time going above and beyond it with risk-taking.  The criticisms \\"it sounds like the first album\\" and \\"it sounds like Nickelback\\" are tired cliches.  A band is going to sound like itself -- which in the case of multi-platinum-selling Daughtry is a good thing.  Saying they sound like Nickelback is a lazy person's way of trying to make it look like they know something about rock music.  The reply to that irrelevant stab is, \\"So what?\\"  Ironically, it's much more of a compliment than a put-down.   I dare anybody to listen to No Surprise three times and not be humming it the next day.  If you want hard rock, listen to You Don't Belong.  For country, go with Tennessee Line featuring Vince Gill.  If Christian music is your thing, give a listen to Open Up Your Eyes, with its life-ever-after theme.  There is not a song on Leave This Town that doesn't have a singable chorus and a hummable hook.  If you like to think of yourself as a rebel, and you're not comfortable liking what 5 million other people like, give it a shot.  Sometimes the mainstream is cool.
0441017177|5.0|Some of the best science fiction works I have read have come from former engineers, physicists or scientist that have become science fiction authors and fully understand the technology they are creating. They provide a framework of believability that makes the story much more interesting to read.    Reynold's has truly produced a great piece of work that can only be compared to one other great science fiction author, Arthur C. Clark. Both writers have different writing styles, but in the end they know how to engineer a masterpiece that keeps on climaxing throughout the book. I rarely ever write a review, simply because I don't know if I can provide feedback that might be useful to other readers.  Since I use the feedback myself, I thought I should give back.    After looking at my bookshelf, which is now full, which is why I read on a Kindle these days, I notice that I have read science fiction authors like Clark, Niven, Card, Asimov, Hamilton, Baxter, Adams, Reynolds, etc. So when I say this is one of the best pieces of work I have read in a long time, you understand what I am comparing it to.    This book needs no sequel and ends as goods as it begins. Thanks for the great work.

Don't know if a majority of readers are already aware of this. So, as I continued reading the book I kept sensing connections between Cohn and jake, to Hemingway. I think both characters contained certain traits which related to Hemingway's own personal characteristics. I think Hemingway wished he could have been more like Jake in instances of his own life. How Jake was very strong and in control of his emotions, and his resistance to falling absolutly in love with Lady Ashley. Cohn on the other hand makes a complete fool of himself by going head over heels for Lady Ashley. Love showed how weak Cohn is, and how strong, and cool Jake was. Maybe Hemingway's wished he could been more able to be like Jake, and therefore impervious to ever becoming heart-broken. Good read, there's a lot more I want to talk about, but better read it again before I start making anymore conclusions. Great read for anyone!
B001QOOCTE|4.0|When I played the CD, I was deeply touched by the music. It grabbed at me and wouldn't let me go until I had played each song several times. However, when I finally played the DVD some weeks later, I was floored by the way the makers of this music wove themselves together from so many different cultures and musical traditions. Don't wait to watch the DVD, even if you have to go over to a friend's house to arrange a viewing. If you love music and especially if you love music-making, you will find yourself deeply touched by the DVD's elegant simplicity. I have played on the streets of New Orleans, Seattle, France and Belgium, etc. Watching the DVD, I recognized a special breed of musician -- hearty souls who love and live their lives for music, come what may. Their many lifetimes of whole-hearted dedication to music shines through every note.

0756405890|2.0|I had complicated feelings about this book. On one hand, I loved Patrick Rothfuss's writing style and the way he set up the world. He managed to keep me engaged throughout the book, the settings were detailed, Sympathy was incredibly clever, the University was cool--the set-up was just fantastic. The idea was intriguing, as well; I haven't read many, if any, books with this premise. The whole idea is that Kvothe is already a legend, and is recording his story.    However, the main character got in the way.    I found Kvothe to be unrelatable and irritating. I don't want to give too much away, but I didn't feel anything for him during any of his hardships. The whole book is just a platform for Mr. Rothfuss to proclaim how amazing his protagonist is. At one point, Kvothe's first mentor tells Kvothe's parents that their son will excel at anything he does, and become the greatest whatever the world has ever seen. Kvothe has no flaws--he's a genius, he's the most talented musician anyone has ever seen, he rescues people, he makes friends, he's the 'plucky underdog' who stands up the mean, rich bully--he's annoying! True, there are books where you're supposed to dislike the main character, but this isn't one of them. I'm supposed to like him, but he's too convinced of his own superiority.      I also disliked Kvothe's girlfriend. She changes her name often, but Kvothe calls her Denna. She's basically a female Kvothe, which explains why they get on so well. However, where Kvothe is learning Sympathy, Denna is essentially a gold-digger. But it's all good, because she's beautiful and life is hard for attractive, single women! I sort of understand what Mr. Rothfuss is trying to explain when another character gives Kvothe this whole speech on why Denna acts like she does, but it just came off as \\"That's all attractive women can do!\\"     Actually, that was the thing I disliked about this world--women don't really show up. There are some people in Kvothe's troup at the beginning, there are a few women learning Sympathy, and there's Denna. I would be fine with what Denna does to survive if it had been handled better, but it wasn't. She's portrayed as bright, and women are allowed into the University--why doesn't she study and apply? She's apparently the only musician who can rival Kvothe--why doesn't she try to make a name for herself as a singer and get a patron? She's apparently a good actress--why not act? The justification for what she does is basically \\"she's hot and it's easy money.\\"     A lot of the minor characters were more enjoyable--Devon and Bast, especially, except for when they're sucking up to Kvothe. Interactions between the two of them are...interesting, to say the least. However, a lot of the minor characters simply provide a background that Kvothe can shine against. They're there to make him look good. In general, the teachers either love Kvothe or hate him. The ones who love him are intelligent, good people, while the ones who hate him are EEEEEEEEVIL pigs or idiots.     Master Elodin is one of the exceptions. He's totally mad, and is my favorite character in the book. Also, he convinced Kvothe to jump off a roof, which is reason enough to love him. The librarian, too, is likable. He catches Kvothe with a candle in a stack of old, rare books and bans him from the library. He's overprotective of his books, which I can totally relate to.    Overall, I would give this book 2 1/2 stars, but I'm rounding it down to two. While I did enjoy Mr. Rothfuss's writing style immensely, his characters need a major overhaul. I won't buy the next books, but if I could borrow them from a friend, I would read them, just to see if the characters get more likeable.    The reasons legends work is because the characters in them are legends. They don't need to be human; we don't expect them to be, we don't want them to be. Patrick Rothfuss tried to make a hero a person, and didn't quite get it right.
0307473465|4.0|This novel felt like three different novellas, tied together. This first, where a 15 year old has an affair with an older woman in Germany in the 30's, is quite good. Part 2, the Nazi war crime trial, is the least engaging. Part 3, the post-trial era, pulls together the first two parts, and I enjoyed that quite a bit. While I never quite felt as connected to the narrator as I would have liked, I enjoyed this original novel.

The way the disks are packaged, there is a set of plastic cards (one for each disk) and a set for each box you need to rummage through trying to figure out what actually is on the disks.<br /><br />The whole set could have been much more user- and eco-friendly if it had simply been packaged with a slip case and a well-labeled box for each season that (gasp!) listed the episodes for that season on the back of the box.  Better yet, geniuses who put this set together could probably have created a small booklet to put into the larger sleeve that would have listed episodes in order (perhaps with dates and a few lines of plot summary)and then added an appendix listing each episode by name and location on the set. 0545123267|5.0|I was excited but nervous to read this one. There's so much buzz surrounding it and I didn't want to be let down. I shouldn't have been nervous-this book exceeded my expectations and I was drawn in to Sam and Grace's story.<br /><br />Shiver is paranormal romance at its best. This book did exactly what I want other paranormal romances to do (I'm looking at you Twilight). The story draws you in and will not let you go. You are engaged in the characters. You care about what happens and you're left breathless and have to keep turning the pages. This is a book that when I stopped reading, I had to come out of a reading fog because I would be so drawn into the story it took me a minute to remember where I was. This is one I'm already passing on to friends and talking up because I want to share it with everyone.<br /><br />Sam and Grace are both strong characters who are also flawed. They have numerous obstacles to overcome and life isn't sunshine and roses for either of them. I knew why Grace was attracted to Sam, and it wasn't just because he was a hot guy-he had depth. He was sweet and charming, but was also broken, which made him an interesting character.<br /><br />The chapters are told in alternating viewpoints, so you really get inside both Sam and Grace and learn who they really are. I thought this would be confusing, but after I read a few chapters I got used to it and it was easy to follow who was telling the story.<br /><br />Maggie Stiefvater's writing is very lyrical and poetic. The story isn't full of action, but that was ok. The story may move at a slower pace than other books, but the plot unfolds quickly. There are multiple layers to the story and that adds to the delight of the reader as you unravel the many stories that are wrapped up here. Yes, it's mainly Sam and Grace's story, but there are other stories and characters that I can't wait to read more about.<br /><br />There are some loose ends, but I think with the sequels we'll learn more about the wolves of Mercy Falls and Shiver stands on it's own very well. If any book is going to dethrone Twilight's reign and have adult appeal as well as teens, I think Shiver could do it. A beautifully told story that is a must-read for paranormal fans-add this one to the top of your reading pile!very well.
